welcome.para: These days publishers face questions in many areas where process has formerly been defined by time tested methods and experience. Some of those questions are:

bulletList.listItem: How can the digital transition be managed while maintaining print output?
How can new technologies including agile, cloud, social and mobile be integrated into products and internal processes?
Which new channels and tools are worth pursuing?
How can speed-to-market and customer engagement be improved in new and existing products?
How can financial performance be improved in key areas of operations: inventory, backorders, obsolescence, plant cost, operating expense?
How can metrics be used to link operational performance to business results? Are there other opportunities to use advanced analytics to improve business performance?
How does one go about retooling the workforce in order to create engaging digital products from a classic print-centric organization?
What role should "agile" play in product development and editorial processes? In platform development? In infrastructure technology?
How can the current workforce best be engaged in creating innovative products, services and processes for the future?
What does the future workforce look like and where can they be found?

welcome.para: Treadwell Media Group offers consulting services to help publishers address these concerns with proven results. Our focus is in the application of technology, supplier capabilities and process innovation to improve operating effectiveness. Basically, using bottom line results to help drive top line growth.

Whether you are a publisher interested in building value through the addition of digital delivery and eBook formats, or a content provider or publisher who needs to tune up existing operations, TMG is the single source for solutions.

The founders of TMG have been adding value to publishers and authors in the trade, education, and professional fields for more than a decade, working in both electronic media as well as traditional publishing. Through a creative and consultative approach to solving publisher needs, and drawing on networks of publishing professionals in the field, they support an enterprise dedicated to achievement and profit for their publishing partners. Contact us and find out what we can do for you!

articleHeader.subject: Digital strategy, digital publishing, print on demand, POD

serviceLineDescription.para: Many of the most pressing issues facing publishers involve managing a transition to digital products, channels and marketing into existing print operations while minimizing the effect on their overall economics. For those publishers who are uncertain as to how to best participate in the digital revolution, Treadwell Media Group assists with a range of digital strategy, operations and implementation consulting services.
Some of the questions we've assisted clients answer include:

unOrderedList.listItem: How can the digital transition be managed while maintaining print output?
How can new technologies including agile, cloud, social and mobile be integrated into products and internal processes?
Which new channels and tools are worth pursuing?
How can speed-to-market and customer engagement be improved in new and existing products?
How does one go about retooling the workforce in order to create engaging digital products from a classic print-centric organization?
What role should "agile" play in product development and editorial processes? In platform development? In infrastructure technology?
How can the current workforce best be engaged in creating innovative products, services and processes for the future?
How should pricing of print and digital be handled across channels and geography?
When should DRM be used? When shouldn't it?

What advantages does XYZ (XML, HTML5, EPUB, responsive design, MarkLogic, NoSQL, etc.) technology offer in current processes and products? Should it be used? How can it be effectively integrated in the existing environment?
What's the most effective way to implement custom publishing or sales by chapter?

serviceLineDescription.para: Whether you are concerned about what platforms, formats or channels to pursue, or how best to integrate eBooks and print-on-demand into your existing production process, the Treadwell Media Group team of eBook and traditional publishing experts can help you prepare for your companyâ€™s future.

articleHeader.subject: Publishing, Product Development, Editorial Development, Production

serviceLineDescription.para: Publishers are encountering the need to evolve their product strategies to increasingly consider digital offerings, changing customer needs and expectations, and increasing competitive pressures from both existing players and new market entrants. These trends are increasing the pressure on existing product development processes:

unOrderedList.listItem: Increasing number of products in increasing formats, often with decreasing units per format
Need for reduced time-to-market and ability to rapidly incorporate market feedback in offerings
Need to increase discoverability and relevance to potential readers/customers
Need to synchronize product delivery with marketing, sales, distribution and post-sale support processes
Need to customize and individualize title offerings
Need to integrate technology into products whether useful tools, interactivity or rich media
Integration with platforms: publisher proprietary and those of channel partners

serviceLineDescription.para: As each new product is introduced, it is generally accompanied by its own development process, creating a situation where activities are fragmented, unpredictable and in general yield insufficient scale for maximum effectiveness, regardless of whether effectiveness is defined by cost, speed, capacity or flexibility.

At Treadwell Media Group we've lived through these challenges and have implemented processes, organization and technology to relieve the pain. While there is no panacea, all solutions will have one or more key elements:

unOrderedList.listItem: Differentiation in customer-facing offerings.
Scalable platforms behind the scenes for editorial, production, content management and rights management functions.
Alignment with the product strategy whether the introduction of a few, highly-differentiated products, or a large number of low cost titles.
Alignment and coordination of centralized functions with product needs via workflow and planning tools.
Standards where they're invisible, differentiation where they're not.
Ability to quickly and easily re-use content where appropriate.
Synchronized delivery of all output and intermediate formats via continuous integration, "XML-first" and other process automation.
Synchronized and consistent design across all output formats and devices via responsive design techniques.
Direct feedback loops on product usage, competitor offerings and social trends straight into the product development teams.

serviceLineDescription.para: Let TMG come in and discuss your product development processes and we'll help you determine if any of these solutions are appropriate for you.

articleHeader.subject: Publishing, Supply Chain, Order Management, Transportation, Warehousing, Distribution, Inventory Management, Forecasting

serviceLineDescription.para: With so much attention on digital products and processes, supply chain operations are an often overlooked source of savings, working capital, customer satisfaction and business efficiency. Typically the supply chain will consist of the Order to Cash (OTC) and Procure to Pay (PTP) processes and will encompass well over 50% of P&L cost and balance sheet investment. Frequently observed opportunities include:

unOrderedList.listItem: Supply chain integration via shared forecasts and digital transactions
Print sourcing optimization including offshore, onshore and print on demand (POD). This often integrates well with programs to manage printers and paper suppliers more effectively.
Effective distribution of accurate title metadata
Tailoring inventory levels to changing print demand via a time-phased sales & operations planning process
Integration of customer data into print planning and sales operations. This is particularly valuable if there are shifts in channel patterns or title demand is seasonal or unpredictable.
Use of channel-based print on demand to reduce impact of temporary out-of-stock lost sales

serviceLineDescription.para: Treadwell Media Group takes a holistic view of the supply chain starting with the customer service goals of the company including delivery times, fill rates, and flexibility. These translate into structural supply chain decisions...

unOrderedList.listItem: Appropriate mix of make-to-stock and make-to-order policies, possibly integrating custom or individualized printing if required by the product strategy

Inventory deployment to owned and partner facilities, whether third party or wholesale. These decisions are often paired with the company's overall go to market strategy, but can also be considered independently.
Number, location, and role of distribution facilities along with whether they are owned or outsourced

serviceLineDescription.para: ...functional decisions...

unOrderedList.listItem:
Order management
eCommerce integration with traditional credit sales Management of channel versus consumer orders Reconciliation of traditional order/pack/ship revenue models with sales-report driven revenue and online license, activation and access models Rep commission management

Warehouse management
Receive, pick, pack, ship automation and flow

Transportation management
Shipment scheduling, consolidation and freight bill audit programs

Inventory management
Integration of demand forecasts, return forecasts, with inventory planning and optimal print strategy

serviceLineDescription.para: ...and supporting organizational elements:

unOrderedList.listItem: Policy
Process
Organization
Technology
Infrastructure

serviceLineDescription.para: Contact TMG to review your supply chain challenges and we'll devise a strategy specifically for your company.

articleHeader.subject: Vendor Management, Sourcing, Purchasing, Outsourcing, Offshoring

serviceLineDescription.para: Establishing and effectively managing third party relationships is a key element in extending the reach and capabilities of a publishing enterprise and managing an uneven flow of work over the course of time. It allows use of specialized expertise as needed and reduces the effective cost of operations. At the same time there are legal risks associated with excessive or improper use of freelancers, and commonly accepted practices may not yield the innovative results necessary for success today.

At Treadwell Media Group we take a category approach to vendor management, looking at each type of good or service in terms of its importance to the business and the difficulty of the particular market. We extract and consolidate the expectations of the management team in each category in terms of time, quality and cost performance, and consolidate them with our experience and best practice. These expectations then lead to the optimal vendor strategy by category:

unOrderedList.listItem: Strategic partnerships
Blanket contracts
Scales-based purchasing
Spot purchasing

serviceLineDescription.para: We have found that for many critical categories in product development and supply chain operations, developing strategic partnerships and consolidating volume into these partnerships can result in significant cost reduction and decreased time to market. Other possibilities include:

unOrderedList.listItem: Outsourcing / nearshoring / offshoring
Vendor consolidation
Independent contractor / freelancer program consolidation
Consolidation of services across multiple related categories into full service suppliers
Directed buy programs

serviceLineDescription.para: Once a vendor management strategy has been identified we then can assist in executing Request for Information (RFI), Request for Proposal (RFP) processes and negotiating Master Service Agreement (MSA) or Statement of Work (SOW) contracts. This will often lead to supply chain integration activities such as sharing forecasts of upcoming work and using EDI / XBITS to facilitate transactions.
Invite TMG in for a discussion and we'll determine which approaches sound right for you!

articleHeader.subject: Treadwell Media Group Services, Book Publishing, Publishing, Technology, Product Technology, Integration

serviceLineDescription.para: Whether due to an environment of systematic underinvestment in technology, successive investments in different platforms and technologies, or growth through acquisition, most publishers are facing a variety of technology challenges. At Treadwell Media Group our perspective is that effective technology management starts with a strong technology management base upon which an evolving digital toolkit of cloud, social, analytics, mobile and rich media is used to drive rapid customer-facing innovation and internally-facing scalability and business efficiency.

Modern customer-facing products and platforms require rapid rollout of features and capabilities driven by strong product management and architectural discipline paired with agile development processes. Reconciliation of often-conflicting and rapidly changing priorities in a fast-paced and evolving technology environment are the biggest challenges, particularly as these new demands apply pressure to longer-cycle and more traditional editorial processes.

In internally-facing, non-product applications, this focus on innovation and agility shifts toward an emphasis on enabling business productivity via carefully defined and managed IT services. Internal priorities are set in consultation with operating executives to determine which services will drive the greatest business value. These are then designed and implemented in a controlled operations management environment on a defined technology stack.
Whatever your technology management challenges:

unOrderedList.listItem: Product platform rationalization
Implementation of agile development technologies in a traditional IT or editorial environment
Incorporation of mobile, cloud, analytics, social and rich media into customer-facing or internal applications
Implementation of a disciplined operations management environment

serviceLineDescription.para: Treadwell Media Group can help. Give us a call!

articleHeader.subject: Treadwell Media Group, Book Publishing, Contracts, Rights Management, DRM, Digital Rights Management, Ken Brooks, Publishing Dimensions

serviceLineDescription.para: Treadwell Media Group provides innovative solutions in capturing information on publishers' largest asset: the rights that they control and exploit. Our solutions include cost-effective capture of rights data from author and subrights contracts and integration of that data into popular rights management services, applications and on-line sales channels.
By having rights information digitized and readily accessible in a rights management system, publishers achieve a number of direct revenue benefits:

unOrderedList.listItem: The capture of missed revenue opportunities including unsold sub-rights (beyond the frontlist), renegotiation of expiring deals, and uncollected royalties from deals that have already been negotiated.
Generating new revenue streams from digital publishing, content recombination, and from electronic rights brokerage exchanges.
Facilitation of better publishing decisions through go/no-go decisions based not just on anecdotal evidence but also on true understanding of rights sales history of similar titles.
Increasing margin / reducing write-offs by enabling the targeting of sales efforts to titles with unearned advances.
Reducing time-to-market in evaluating new revenue opportunities by enabling rapid determination of the rights held.

serviceLineDescription.para: Beyond the direct revenue benefits of having rights information readily available, capturing contracts in digital form yields substantial productivity, timeliness and business continuation benefits over time. Some of these include:

unOrderedList.listItem: Increasing margin by reducing staff time and effort associated with the management of contracts including indexing, storage and retrieval. These benefits accrue across the organization in legal, rights marketing, editorial, finance, and royalty departments.
Better disaster recovery - fewer in-process contracts lost, faster speed of recovery and increased ability to store multiple copies in separate remote locations.
More timely initial entry of data into enterprise systems including royalties, order processing, financial, production, and editorial systems
Reduction of document management expense associated with storage and retrieval of paper contracts
More timely response to internal and external inquiries on contract-related issues

serviceLineDescription.para: Publishers achieve a number of advantages from the Treadwell Media Group approach:

unOrderedList.listItem: High quality, consistent rights data output requiring little intervention for validation
A cost-effective solution offering quick turnaround on most types of contracts
Experienced staff with traditional and electronic publishing experience
Knowledge of functional and data requirements of most rights management systems
Delivery of rights information to publisher-specified channels of distribution
Detailed tracking of contract conversion through each stage of production
Real-time availability of production status via secure web page
Hassle-free customer service with knowledgeable representatives
Largest conversion capacity in the industry
Exceptionally fast ramp-up capability
Built in disaster recovery through site mirroring and multiple redundant conversion sites
Global state-of-the-art facilities and telecommunications network

serviceLineDescription.para: Our credentials in rights management are wide and varied. Some of our representative experiences include:

project.projectDescription: Developed a rights management strategy for a large trade publisher resulting in a major successful systems implementation.

Working with a large university press we developed the design of a rights database incorporating territories, languages, and types of rights in order to support their modernization and digital commerce initiatives.

In conjunction with an academic press developed the XML Document Type Definition (DTD) used to capture head contract and subrights contract terms, conditions and rights grant. We prototyped it's use in capturing a number of different contract types.

Developed a web-based cookbook application enabling a consumer to select among a database of more than 2000 recipes, enter his/her own recipes and other personalizing material and receive a printed cookbook within 5 business days. the project involved developing a recipe DTD, converting the recipes from various hardcopy and electronic forms, building a web user interface linked in with an XML database, and developing the XSLT-driven output transformations.

Timed to release simultaneously with Mel Gibson's Passion movie, developed a web-based application allowing readers to see how Matthew, Mark, Luke and John narrated the events of the Passion, Crucifixion and Resurrection. The application utilized an index of the main events to generate a 4-column parallel version to show the presentation of each event in each of the Gospels. Readers were allowed to pick the translation desired (multiple English- and Spanish-language versions were made available) and the particular events desired. A web presentation was developed that could then be downloaded as a PDF or requested as a print-on-demand edition.

Developed a web-based application allowing a reader to simultaneously view two translations of the Bible in either HTML or PDF, and then order a custom printed and bound version for delivery to their home for offline use. The project used XML and XSLT technology on generally available translations of the Bible existing in OSIS 2.1 markup.
Participated in the business SIG of the Open eBook Foundation.
Participated in the development of the aggregator DTD developed by the PRISM working group.

For a Higher Ed publisher evaluated the economics to publisher, retailer, student and used book wholesaler of traditional buy/sell, consignment, rental and other business models. Identified key decision criteria and developed recommended approach forward.
For a large trade publisher evaluated a number of alternatives for distributing into Canada including an owned operation, cross-docking, and use of third-party distributors.
Developed a rights management strategy for a large trade publisher resulting in a major successful systems implementation.
Evaluated the extent to which textbooks sold overseas were being diverted back into the U.S. market and what possible actions might be that publishers could take to address the problem.

Served as process architect in 2 separate publishing industry SAP installations (Bantam Doubleday Dell, now part of Random House, and Simon & Schuster) across production, inventory management, editorial, order processing, distribution and finance functions.

At Bantam Doubleday Dell implemented improvements in vendor relationship management that resulted in a reduction of $2.1 million in pricing, reduced contract print cycle by 15-days, and improved on-time delivery to 99+ percent. BDD's president was quoted in Publishers Weekly naming manufacturing cost reduction as one of the three sources of BDD's best year ever.

At Bantam Doubleday Dell implemented standardization measures that with no perceptible change in variety of books published decreased paper raw material inventory from $8.5 million to $6.2 million and had no effect on printing lead times.

project.projectType: Rights Management data and functional modeling
project.projectDescription: As part of a customer/consultant/software provider team, developed the rights management data and functional model used by SAP for their implementation of a rights management module.
Reduced book development cycle by 33% at a large trade publisher, now part of Random House, through process mapping and redesign.

For a large trade publisher evaluated the impact of consignment sale of inventory. Although the balance sheet impact of the move was favorable, issues with delayed revenue recognition prevented implementation.

Performed industry analysis comparing net effective discounts offered across a range of publishers taking into account discount, RDC and freight terms, coop allowances and other common terms of sale. Analysis was used to evaluate a proposed publisher terms of sale change for retail attractiveness.

At Bantam Doubleday Dell established a supply management/corporate purchasing function resulting in $1 million in purchased goods and services reductions, and an additional $2 million targeted for FY 94/95 (since attained).

Merged Simon &Schuster's (pre-Viacom sale) customer service and credit departments to create "one face to the customer", leading to Simon & Schuster being recognized by our customers as being "most improved" in customer service in the 1997 annual Market Partners survey of publisher performance.
At Simon & Schuster implemented key account management strategy to focus on joint improvement in margin and operating efficiencies with our customers.
Increased call center productivity by 7%, simultaneously increasing attainment of target service levels.

At a large trade publisher implemented substantial changes to AR and Credit functions reducing DSO in the last 12 months by 10%. Other benefits achieved included reducing average time to clear customer deductions by almost 100 days with no change in percent written off, reducing the unmatched deduction balance by over 25%; doubled average speed of cash application; and substantially improved methods of cash receipts forecasting, leading to more reliable estimates of cash, A/R component balances, and DSO.

At Simon &Schuster reduced education transportation cost per unit by over 6% (both gross and net) through consolidation of carriers used and negotiation around specific rates on heavily traveled lanes.
Provided expert testimony regarding reasonable royalty rates in a print-on-demand patent infringement case.
Provided expert testimony regarding industry supply chain practices in a suit against a self-publishing company.
Evaluated publisher and retailer perception of an eBook wholesale company as a basis for determining future strategy.
Developed and implemented an eBook and print-on-demand distribution strategy for a small publisher, selecting formats and channels within which to distribute their titles.

Worked with a large Higher Education publisher to evaluate titles and supplementary materials across a variety of disciplines and assess XML "readiness" and determine a strategy for implementing a comprehensive XML-first production process.

In conjunction with an academic press developed the XML Document Type Definition (DTD) used to capture head contract and subrights contract terms, conditions and rights grant. Prototyped it's use in capturing a number of different contract types.

Directed bibliographic data acquisition and database management at Barnes & Noble, Inc. including a redesign of the internal B&N title database (over 1,000,000 titles), and negotiating new agreements with title data vendors.
Directed design and construction of content and metadata archive for EP Ventures, a Philippines-based text and image conversion operation.

Developed high-level design to archive content in a format-neutral repository and generate on-the-fly formats including OEB, HTML 4.0, Microsoft Reader, Palm Digital Media, Gemstar and Adobe eBook Reader formats. Initiated implementation of this concept at EP Ventures and another large provider of conversion services.
For Barnes & Noble implemented a centralized print-on-demand operation with the capacity to print 45,000 books per month.

Founded a print-on-demand and eBook publishing entity that has more than 1,500 titles published and being sold through online retail and wholesale channels such as bn.com and Lightning Source. Program required the development of editorial, managing editorial, rights clearance and production capabilities within a very small team with no previous experience in these functions.

At Barnes & Noble directed a feasibility study of an in-store print-on-demand and kiosk-based book delivery system. Study demonstrated that insufficient content existed in appropriate format at the time to make such a system sufficiently appealing to customers to be viable.
Participated in the original AAP Emerging Technologies Committee that formulated the need for and structure of the Digital Object Identifier (DOI).
Participated in the ONIX for subrights committee convened at Frankfurt 2001. The purpose of the committee is to define metadata standards around exchange of rights information.

articleHeader.subject: eBook Business Issues
articleHeader.source: Publishing 2001: Attitudes to Technological Change, 2001, BPI Communications.
articleHeader.description: Article presents a strategic framework to assist publishers in determining in which formats, platforms and channels they should be making their content available.

articleHeader.subject: eBook Business Issues
articleHeader.source: Digital Content Management for Publishing conference on July 24, 2001.

articleHeader.articleTitle: eBook Supply Chain: Opportunities and Challenges
articleHeader.subject: eBook Business Issues
articleHeader.source: Supply Chain Seminar, Frankfurt Book Fair, on October 9, 2001

articleHeader.subject: eBook Production Issues
articleHeader.description: Article describing the most common formats for eBooks and the advantages of each.

articleHeader.source: Presentation given at Seybold San Francisco, 2001 on September 27, 2001
articleHeader.description: eBook formats and recommendations on which publishers should implement

articleHeader.subject: eBook Production Issues
articleHeader.description: Cost-effective methods that publishers can use to incrementally convert their books into various eBook formats based on expected sales in each format. Presentation also includes high-level diagrams illustrating the most common types of conversion and associated issues.

articleHeader.subject: Print On Demand
articleHeader.source: PIRA Digital Print World conference, London, on February 13, 2001
articleHeader.description: The presentation covers the economic drivers of print-on-demand, distinctions between central and distributed print-on-demand and addresses barriers to acceptance of distributed print-on-demand.

articleHeader.articleTitle: Print-on-Demand in the Book Supply Chain
articleHeader.subject: Print On Demand
articleHeader.description: Article on Print-on-Demand discussing its use at various levels of the Book Supply Chain: Publisher, Wholesaler and Retailer. The article encompasses material from a number of 2001 presentations on Print-on-Demand issues.

articleHeader.subject: Rights Management
articleHeader.source: Discussion notes from Publishers Lunch, New York, June 20, 2001
articleHeader.description: Presents the case that all publishing transactions have a rights element that is only growing more important.

articleHeader.subject: Production
articleHeader.source: Digital Smart Factory Panel Discussion, June 24, 2003
articleHeader.description: Describes a framework for implementing XML within the editorial and production workflows of traditional publishing operations.

articleHeader.subject: Production
articleHeader.description: Describes the process of implementing Digital Object Identifiers to increase web traffic and sales.

articleHeader.articleTitle: Why a Rolling Monthly Demand Forecast?
articleHeader.subject: Inventory Management
articleHeader.description: Why should publishers go to the effort of creating a monthly, title-level, rolling forecast?

articleHeader.subject: Production
articleHeader.description: Describes issues facing Higher Education Publishers and their current and future impact on key publishing processes.

articleHeader.articleTitle: Making the Digital Leap: Protecting the Value of Your Business in the Migration from Print to Electronic
articleHeader.subject: Digital Strategy
articleHeader.description: Describes steps publishers can take to maintain value while converting processes, systems and workforce to generate digital products.

biography.name: Kenneth M. Brooks, Jr.
biography.title: President
biography.biodescription: Mr. Brooks was formerly senior vice president, global production and manufacturing services at Cengage Learning where his responsibilities included the development, production, and manufacturing of textbooks and reference content in print and digital formats. Prior to his position at Cengage Learning, Ken was president and founder of Publishing Dimensions, a digital content services company focused in the eBook and digital strategy space. Over the course of his career, Ken has founded a Philippines-based text conversion company; a public domain publishing imprint; and a distribution-center based print-on-demand operation and has worked in trade, higher education, reference, professional and K-12 publishing sectors. He has held several senior management positions in publishing, including vice president of digital content at Barnes & Noble, vice president of operations, production, and strategic planning at Bantam Doubleday Dell, and vice president of customer operations at Simon & Schuster. Prior to his entry into publishing, Ken was a senior manager in Andersen Consulting's logistics strategy practice.

faqquestion.para: What does Treadwell Media Group do?

faqanswer.para: Treadwell Media Group provides innovative solutions to publishers in generating revenue through evolving digital channels. These solutions include cost-effective conversion of content from electronic and paper sources into eBook and print-on-demand files, and placement of content into publisher-specified channels of distribution. For those publishers that may be uncertain as to how best proceed in the digital marketplace, Treadwell Media Group also delivers a range of consulting services in both electronic and traditional publishing.

resource.resourceDescription: Amazon, one of the largest and most popular online book sites, also sells a broad range of products across multiple categories to a worldwide audience. The hallmarks of their business are service, convenience, and a laser-like customer-centric focus. In addition to revenue sharing arrangements, they offer third-party partners expertise and co-sourcing in e-commerce, customer service, and technology.
Fictionwise sells a wide variety of copy-protected and unencrypted eBooks in virtually all available formats.

Borders is a leading books and mortar bookstore chain that partners with Amazon for e-commerce. From more than 1,200 stores around the world, Borders supplies books, music, and movies to enrich and entertain. The large specialty retailer, Waldenbooks, is a division of Borders.

From its vast warehouse links, B&N supplies more than 1 million titles for immediate delivery â€“ more than any other online bookseller. B&N considers itself a premier destination for books, music, DVDs, Audiobooks, and offers a Meet the Writers program, B&N Jr., specializing in childrenâ€™s books, videos and music, and a music store with downloadable clips.

A family of independent bookseller websites, and the e-commerce arm of the American Booksellers Association BookSense program. News about local authors and events is showcased in tis book community site.

The third largest book retailer in the US operating more than 200 stores in the southeastern US. It supports superstores, traditional â€˜Booklandâ€™ shops, and the Joe Muggs newstands as a new store/cafÃ© concept in addition to its e-commerce presence.

A family-owned, Portland-based bookstore chain with significant community involvement, Powells was the first to popularize the combination of new and used, hardcover and paperbacks under one roof. They create reader-centered, destination bookstore environments, and were among the earliest to establish online bookselling.

The largest book and media fair in the world, the Frankfurt Book Fair, held in October each year, hosts exhibitors from over 100 countries, attracts over 7,000 exhibitors, and is considered to be not only about books but is the most important international trading fair globally for rights and licenses.

The London Book Fair is the leading spring forum for booksellers, publishers, librarians and book production services worldwide. Timed to provide a concentrated 3-day trading and educational platform offering access to the world's books and other forms of media, publishing industry professionals use it to make business contacts, sell rights, and exchange shared knowledge.

Book Expo America combines the largest selection of English language titles from around the world, bringing together booksellers along with other industry professionals for networking and rights sales, in addition to a rich program of educational events. It rotates in location around several of the largest American cities in the late spring each year.

A dedicated marketplace for publishing professionals to find critical information and unique databases, find each other, and to do business better electronically. Nearly 30,000 professionals visit the site to read Publishers Lunch, a popular category of Publishers Marketplace. It is the industryâ€™s â€œdaily essential read.â€ Each report gathers stories from all over the web and print of interest to the professional trade book community, along with original reporting, plus a little perspective and the occasional wisecrack added in.

The leading trade periodical publication to the publishing industry. A must-read (or at least must-skim) for every publishing professional, it is available in print and online. PW also sponsors educational forums, engages with strategic partners to foster greater information exchange and education, and generally supports business growth and development among professional publishers.
eReader.com is the first electronic book publisher to offer contemporary fiction and non-fiction books, newspapers, and magazines for reading on handheld computers.

AdobeÂ® Digital Editions is an engaging new way to read and manage eBooks and other digital publications. It is built from the ground up as a lightweight rich Internet application (RIA). Adobe Digital Editions works online and offline and supports PDF- and XHTML-based content as well as Adobe FlashÂ® SWF for rich interactivity.

eBooks.com aims to be the pre-eminent eBookstore on the Internet, selling whole books, chapters and pages of books online from the world's leading publishers. eBooks can be purchased and downloaded immediately by customers anywhere in the world at prices that are cheaper than printed books. Their list currently offers 80,000 popular, professional and academic eBooks. As with all eBooks formats, additional channel sales and royalty benefits are available to publishers and authors.

Microsoft revolutionized eBook reading with the introduction of the Microsoft Reader software in 2001. With its ClearType technology to increase the crispness of font presentation, and many features designed to enhance the digital reading experience Microsoft Reader has been one of the primary mass market readers since its launch. Microsoft has not released an update to the reader since 2003, and it appears to be putting its resources behind alternate software used by the New York Times to present its digital editions.

Franklin Electronic Publishers, Inc., designs, develops, publishes, and distributes globally innovative electronic language learning solutions on handheld devices, memory media cards, and via Internet downloads. From Franklinâ€™s introduction of the worldâ€™s first handheld reference device in 1986, the company has been exploiting the potential of eBooks to create a fundamentally new way of reading. Their goal was to build upon their expertise as the worldwide leader in eBooks in several ways. First, they created an early generation in eBook hardware with eBookman, the worldâ€™s first handheld eBook reader that had both an open but secure architecture, was affordable, portable, and provided an optimal reading experience. Second, they brought Franklinâ€™s high-quality eBook content to a wide audience of users by making it available for any platform. Third, they transformed their website into an eBookstore with a wide range of titles from respected content providers. Today, Franklin focuses on the educator and global language markets as well.

Mobipocket is the universal reader for PDAs, PCs and Smartphones: the Mobipocket software is freely downloadable and consists of publishing and reading tools dedicated to cross-platform reading. Their software is developed internally by Mobipocket and allows owners of PDAs to have access to a personalized press review, the reading of classic and contemporary eBooks, and a secure reading system. Mobipocket is now owned by amazon.com
Lightning Source, Inc., a subsidiary and OneSource partner of Ingram Industries, Inc., offers a package of digital fulfillment and printing services including print-on-demand, to the book industry.
Owned by amazon.com and integrated into their distribution system, BookSurge operates multiple POD business models including drop ship, short run and distribution approaches.

Baker & Taylor is a leading supplier of books, movies, music, and information products to libraries and retailers worldwide. The BTOL website will provide you with up-to-date information about Baker & Taylor, as well as important information for your market.

Ingram Book Group is a wholesale distributor to booksellers, librarians, and specialty retailers, offering almost 1 million titles including books, audiobooks, music, hard-to-find and Spanish-language titles. Ingram assists its partner programs through a series of innovations including ipage and OneSource.

MPI is the first consulting firm dedicated to consumer publishing. Its principals have over 40 years of industry experience relating to strategic planning, content development, marketing, sales and fulfilment, operations and executive search. Established in 1990, the firm also issues Publishing Trends, a monthly newsletter read by senior publishing professionals in 30 countries around the world, and writes regular columns for Inside.com.

Publishers Lunch is the industry's "daily essential read," now shared with well over 8,000 publishing people every day. Each report gathers together stories from all over the web and print of interest to the professional trade book community, along with original reporting, plus a little perspective and the occasional wisecrack added in.

The International Digital Publishing Forum is an international trade and standards organization. Its members consist of hardware and software companies, publishers, authors, users of electronic books, and related organizations whose common goals are to establish specifications and standards for electronic publishing. The Forumâ€™s goal is to foster the development of applications and products that will benefit creators of content, makers of reading systems, and, most importantly, consumers.

One of the latest handheld readers for eBooks, featuring breakthrough technology in its â€œelectronic paperâ€ display, touted to be as easy to read as a printed page. Only a half-inch thick, and at 9 ounces, it presents an attractive alternative for eBook reading. The battery holds for up to 7,500 page turns.There are currently two models of the Sony Reader available: The original PRS-500 and the newer PRS-505.

The amazon Kindle is a competititor to the SonyReader, arriving with an 800 by 600 pixel display, 256MB of RAM, and a scroll wheel, mini USB port, and a headphone jack. It carries the added feature of EV-DO cellular data.

The iLiad is a portable device that lets you read and write as you do on paper in a portable format. Books, newspapers and documents can be carried and displayed on a device as small and light as a book. Unlike typical screens, the iLiad offers good readability in bright sunlight. With the iLiad can you also send, receive and share documents via wireless downloads or USB connection. The screen image is stable, providing a more comfortable reading experience than with a typical screen.
Education compositor located in Pondicherry, India. Integra recently purchased Elm Street, though which they offer North American project management and development editorial services.

Now known as ICC Macmillan, Interactive Composition Corporation is a full-service provider offering a range of typesetting and publishing services. With the resources of Macmillan India behind them, ICC offers high quality and significant capacity across all sectors of publishing.
International Typesetting and Composition, or ITC, has been acquired by Infomedia India. ITC is one of the better typesetters for educational material.
Development editorial for Real Estate.
Development editorial for Tech and Trades work.
Development editorial for Business & Economics.
Lachina does high quality work on complex, technical materials. They offer a comprehensive range of editorial, graphics, and production services. They are located in Cleveland, Ohio.
Pre-Press Company, now Pre-PressPMG, is owned by the Premedia Group. They focus on composition, art and production services for educational publishers. Pre-Press PMG is located in Plymouth, MA.

S4Carlisle represents the merger of S4 Ind Software Pvt. Ldt. and Carlisle Publishing Services. They have offices in Dubuque, Iowa, and Chennai, India. They offer a range of services from development to project management to design, composition and data management.
G&S is a book production service with management, editorial, composition, and prepress expertise located in Austin, Texas. In November, 2005 G&S merged with Newgen Imaging Systems
Based in Chennai, India, Premedia owns Prepress, Beacon, and Westwords.
Formerly known as TechBooks, Aptara has capabilities in development, composition, data conversion, and media production.
Located in Chennai, India and owned by The Carlisle Group...
Graphic World is focused on very complex paging work. Media Production, no 3B2.
Located in Atkinson, NH, GEX is know for extremely effective application of technology to publishing composition problems.
Datapage is located in St. Peters, MO, and provides prepress services that integrate the latest publishing technologies with expertise in traditional typesetting.
An IMS standard for questions and answers for homework and test bank use.

The Sharable Content Object Reference Model (SCORM) is a set of interrelated technical specifications built upon the work of the AICC, IMS and IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) to create one unified â€œcontent model.â€ These specifications enable the reuse of Web-based learning content across multiple environments and products.
A standard promulgated by IEEE to transmit metadata for learning objects. (L)earning (O)bject (M)odel.
A standard used to transmit core bibliographic metadata elements.
(O)nline i(N)formation e(X)change is the standard used by the publishing and bookselling community to exchange bibliographic and commercial information about a title.
WebCT has merged with Blackboard. All information is now on the Blackboard web site.

Angel is a semi-open source CMS. The Angel system is developed and supported by a for-profit company, but supports open standards and enables its community of users to extend portions of the platform.An LMS that supports IMS Common Cartridge, Learning Paths and Gated Assessment.

Popular OpenSource learning management system. Sakai is sponsored by a consortium of schools, including MIT, Stanford, and the University of Michigan. It is gaining large-scale adoptions at major Non-Profit Higher Education universities, driven by two major service vendors â€“ R-Smart and Unicon.

Moodle is a free, Open Source course management system designed using sound pedagogical principles, to help educators create effective online learning communities The platform has been localized in over 75 different languages and has a very active international community of adopters. Because there are no large scale U.S. service vendors for the Moodle platform, it is generally only considered in smaller installations. However, the U.K.â€™s Open University recently adopted Moodle as a standard and has committed to contributing code and resources back to the project.

Merlot (Multimedia Educational Resource for Learning and Online Teaching)is a free and open resource of online learning materials designed primarily for faculty and students of higher education. Merlot is a searchable collection of peer-reviewed online learning materials, or â€œlearning objectsâ€. These are distinct and disparate works, organized by academic discipline, learning objectives and comments. Peers in the Merlot community review and rate contributed â€œlearning objectsâ€, and users can search on the most popular elements.

An online homework delivery service that includes a large database of homework problems based on multiple textbooks in many math, science, and engineering subject areas. This product enables faculty teaching largest lecture classes to assign and track homework that is automatically graded. Students are presented with customized problems sets and receive feedback on their responses.

MIT OCW is a large-scale, web-based electronic publishing initiative funded jointly by the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation , MIT, and the Ab Initio software company. MIT OCW's goals are to provide free, searchable access to MIT's course materials for educators, students, and self-learners around the world; extend the reach and impact of MIT OCW and the "opencourseware" concept.

Tufts OpenCourseWare is part of a new educational movement initiated by MIT that provides free access to course content for everyone online. Tufts' initial course offerings demonstrate the University's strength in the life sciences in addition to its multidisciplinary approach, international perspective and underlying ethic of service to its local, national and international communities. Tufts OCW publishes Tufts course materials, does not require any registration, does not grant credit, degrees, or certificates, does not provide access to Tufts faculty; however feedback is shared.

The OpenCourseWare Consortium is a collaboration of more than 100 higher education institutions and associated organizations from around the world creating a broad and deep body of open educational content using a shared model. The mission of the OpenCourseWare Consortium is to advance education and empower people worldwide through opencourseware.

Banner is the worldâ€™s most widely used collegiate administrative suite of student, financial aid, finance, human resources, and advancement systems. It is a tightly integrated suite of proven, scalable, enterprise-wide applications on a single database, designed to support institutions of all sizes and types. Banner runs on the Oracle RDBMS.
Owned by Oracle

concept.definition: A library associated with an institution of Higher Education supporting post-graduate studies.
That sector of publishing focused on publishing material, generally monographs, of interest to academics. This sector is primarly, though not exclusively, the domain of University Presses.

The management of invoices that have been cut, but for which the cash has not yet been received.AR consists of a number of activities including collections, cash application, credit and debit reconciliation.

Identification of a concept or manuscript suitable for publication through completed contract with authors or sources. "Acquisition" in this context generally refers to acquiring the rights to publish the material.
That sector of publishing focused primarily on providing content for adult consumers across fiction and non-fiction categories.
Alternative ways of organizing the key functions of a publishing enterprise.

The location in the text to which a note refers, generally indicated in print by a symbol or number in a superscript. In HTML an anchor is generally indicated by an underline or blue text color and signifies the starting point of a link.
Media in which the illution of motion is produced by the rapid sequential display of images.
A set of Electronic Data Interchange (EDI) standards from the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). They are now known as ASC X12.
A collection of stories, usually on a common theme.
The software used on a computer or other platform to perform a particular function.
That enterprise technology function that specifies the standards for enterprise systems including operating systems, hardware, databases and information structures.
The determination of the layout and typography of both the interior and cover of a book.
The collection of images that will be used in a particular title. The art program will often be found as a list or series of images at the back of a manuscript.
The transformation of rough sketches or image specifications into art that is production ready.
Evaluation of a student's competence in a body of material. Assessment ranges from low-stakes assessment such as self-tests all the way up to high-stakes assessment in which the student is graded.

Projects to improve the efficiency of corporate assets. These would include advances, inventory and accounts receivable and be reflected in a reduction in the balance sheet assets to support a given level of sales.
The balance sheet value of everything a company owns or is due to it. For publishers the primary assets are receivables, inventory and royalty advances.
A process by which a literary agent or manager solicits bids from publishers for publishing rights to a property.
The rights to publish books and content in audio formats.
The primary audio recording and distribution format prior to the compact disk. An audio cassette contains two small reels of magnetic tape enclosed inside a plastic shell.
Content that is consumed aurally, by listening to it.
The publishing functions used to produce audio books and spoken materials.
The writer of a book or other literary work.
The biographical sketch of the author of a work that is generally contained somewhere on the book jacket or cover, or web site devoted to the title.
The contract between an author and a publisher that lays out the conditions under which a work will be published.
The photograph of the author of a work that is generally contained somewhere on the book jacket or cover, or web site devoted to the title.
The name of the author of a work contained in the book metadata and printed on cover, spine, title page, copyright page and in other places throughout a book and other media.
A biography that is written by the subject of the work.
The back cover of a book. A back cover may be blank, or it may carry promotional or descriptive jacket or other copy intended to be helpful to a potential buyer of the book.
Books published in a previous season but still in print and available for sale.
That part of the text of a book that follows the last page of the last chapter.

An item or line on a customer order that cannot ship due to inventory being out of stock, but which would otherwise ship. This is distinct from a future order which has inventory availability, but is being held for other reasons.
That financial statement on which the assets, liabilities and equity of a company are recorded.
That function of human resources that deals with compensation other than wages, such as health insurance.
An international treaty that defines copyright protection among participating nations. It was signed in 1886 and updated in 1971.
A list of books, articles, etc. used and/or cited in the compilation of a particular title.
That part of the manufacturing of a book in which the pages or signature are bound together.
The part of a book or magazine that holds the pages together

Higher quality paper that does not contain groundwood which has been coated by a process that uses a flexible steel blade to smooth and remove the excess coating. This results in a sheet with a higher coat weight and an optimal print surface.
Groundwood paper that is coated by a process uses a flexible steel blade to smooth and remove the excess coating. This results in a sheet with a higher coat weight and an optimal print surface.
A short summary of a book used for promotion purposes in marketing materials or on the jacket of a book.
Small books for very young children with pages of cardboard to resist chewing or tearing.
The material which gives the covers of hardcover books their stiffness. Generally thick cardboard.
The content of the book, generally consisting of parts, chapters and sections.
Non-wage or salary compensation paid generally once per year upon the attainment of personal or company objectives.

The logical structure of a book including frontmatter, chapters, etc. This is opposed to the physical structure of a book which would include such elements as the jacket, binding, text block and signatures.
The physical form in which a book is published.
A written work that is published as bound pages.
A direct mail marketing organization in which a defined selection of books are sold to members, generally at reduced prices.
The rights to publish a book club edition.
The typography and layout of a book that merges the content of the book with the physical structure of the book.
A publishing convention in which publishers, agents and bookstores come together to buy and sell rights and see what is available for sale.
Information about a book including title, author, ISBN, price, and synopsis.
An entity that produces and distributes books for public consumption.
The major types of book publishing distinguished by the types of customers and uses to which they put information published.
A retailer that deals primarily in books.
The blank space beneath the text on a page. Sometimes a page number, or folio, is displayed in the bottom margin.
A bound set of early pages sent out by a publisher for marketing purposes.

Out of line notes that are inserted into the running text that offer additional information to the body text. Boxed text is set off from the main text typographically through the use of lines creating a box.

A group of nations including the UK and former British colonies that pay allegiance to the British Crown. These include Canada, Australia, Republic of Ireland, Republic of India, New Zealand, and the Republic of South Africa.

England's Statute of Anne (1710) is generally regarded as the first law establishing copyright. It established a public copyright system, established copyright as originating with the author, and established a term for copyright protection.
Television that is synchronously broadcast via radio waves to household receivers. Broadcast television is characterized by homogeneous program offerings that will appeal to a mass audience.
The standard, or large-sized newspaper with pages that are double that of a tabloid. The New York Times is a broadsheet format.
A software program that is used to interact with information on the World Wide Web.
The finance function in which plans are established and monitored for all elements of the financial statements.
A type of adhesive binding in which glue is forced up through slots in each signature during the binding process.
Books about management, economics, finance and investing, accounting, auditing, tax, HR/training and careers, advertising/marketing/sales, real estate, and small business.
The manner in which a company receives money for products or services.
Core systems used by a company to support its mission critical applications. These would include financial systems, sales, order processing, and operations management systems.
Television that is synchronously broadcast via cable to household receivers. Cable television is characterized by a large variety of channels carrying programming of different sorts.
An XML markup model used for tables.
A type of belt press that both prints and binds a book as part of the same process. Cameron belt presses result in inexpensive printing, but are not suitable for halftones or linescreens.
A packet of post card sized advertisements with a common theme that are mailed to consumers.
A binding style characterized by a hard cover (case) made from boards or other stiff material.
Money in bank accounts or other readily accessible form.
A financial projection of future cash flows as part of business planning.
One of the three major financial statements used by businesses to monitor their operations. The cash flow statement profiles all incoming cash streams against outgoing cash streams.
In audio and video production the function of selecting talent for performances.
A form of direct marketing in which a catalog of various items is printed and delivered to a consumer.
The bibiographic data printed on a book's copyright page that is an abbreviated version of the MARC record created by the Library of Congress.
The rights to publish material on CD-ROM.
A CD used in audio players for music or audio books.
A CD for data as opposed to audio.
Also called a mobile phone, a cellular phone is a wireless telephone that sends and receives calls in an area served by cellular towers.
Suppression of a part of a work that is deemed objectionable. Censorship is generally an issue when applied by a government or regulatory agency.
Chain Book retailers consisting of multiple stores.
A grouping of content within a book that generally shares a common theme.
Notation used to describe chemical reactions and relationships.
Books published for use by children.
That sector of publishing focused primarily on providing content for children across fiction and non-fiction categories.

Traditionally this has been the study of the literary works of ancient Greece and Rome. It has taken on a more expanded meaning to represent well-respected literary works of any age prior to the present.
Paper with a surface coating applied to one side (C1S) or two sides (C2S) to allow for better reproduction of halftones and other images.
Companies that aid in the collection of debts from consumers and other businesses.

concept.examples: Follet College Bookstores, Barnes & Noble College
concept.definition: Bookstores associated with institutions of higher education that sell textbooks and many other types of merchandise to students.
Radio stations that are run by the students of a college or university. They generally feature programming that is very different than that provided by commercial stations.

Textbooks that are used in university courses that present a broad scope of material related to a particular discipline. These same textbooks can be used in honors courses or advanced placement courses in high schools.
Logo of a publishing firm generally printed on the title page of a book.
A page in the backmatter on which details of the typography are described.
An illustration that is presented in multiple colors. This is distinct from a black and white illustration or single color illustrations presented in the same color as the text.
An illustrated medium in which the main narrative is presented in images with textual support.
Broadcasting for profit generally via on-air advertising.
Compensation paid only in relation to the value or quantity of what was sold.
Independent sales people, generally self-employed, that work on commission and will generally represent multiple publishers.
Nonprofit radio stations that are generally operated to serve a local interest.
Money paid to employees for fulfilling their daily responsibilities.
That function in a company that determines equitable salary ranges and guidelines for employees and oversees pay and bonus programs.
The transformation of manuscripts to finished pages suitable for printing.
Systems used to compose pages, transforming from a manuscript to final format for printing.

concept.examples: Market Partners, The Idea Logical Company
concept.definition: Providing advice to publishers, wholesalers or others in the publishing industry to solve particular problems of a strategic or operational nature.
Periodicals targeted at consumers that are party supported by subscription and partly by advertising.

The ingestion, maintenance and (generally internal) distribution of content supporting publishing operations. This can support content development and production workflows or be targeted at content post-production.
A Content Management System (CMS) is used to manage a company's digital assets for either development or distribution.
Forms of content that are perceived in different ways, textually, visually, aurally or in some meaningful spatial or temporal combination.
A channel of delivery that is continuously available and in fact requires continuous connection for delivery of content. Examples would include broadcast and two-way channels such as the Internet.
A document in which the terms and conditions of an agreement between two parties is laid out.
That publishing function in which contracts, generally with authors, but also with other parties are executed and maintained.
The amount of gross margin contributed by the sale of a single unit exclusive of overhead costs.
Advertising supported business magazines in which the publisher guarantees to the advertisers that the subscribers are relevant to the advertisers' interests.

The transformation of content from an original format to a derivative format. Often this involves taking content from a previously published format in either paper, PDF or application files into XML or fielded format.
Ensuring grammatical correctness and terminology consistency in a manuscript. Copy editing also generally includes fact checking.

The page placed in the frontmatter of a book that contains key identifying information about the book such as ISBN, CIP data, copyright year and other data that assists in registering and categorizing a book for filing and locating later on as well as other practical functions associated with publishing, cataloguing, filing, or reading a book.
A library associated with a corporation.
Projects to reduce the cost of operations. These projects can be applied to any function.
Courseware in a format suitable for delivery via LMS systems such as Blackboard.

Online content provided to students consisting of learning materials and a course environmement. Generally courseware will include a syllabus, course objectives, core content (text, multimedia and interactive components), tutorial or homework conent, low-stakes assessment/quizzing, and notes and materials provided by an instructor.
Execution of multimedia and interactive components of courseware. This can be delivered as custom coding or in an LMS cartridge format.
Loose weave material used to re-inforce the spine and hinge of a book.
The recombination of content on-the-fly in response to a customer request. This content can be delivered either in physical format via POD or other printing technology, or in digital format.
That function that works with customers in placement of orders, handling of inquiries and resolution of issues.
Working with an author to develop a finished manuscript that is ready for production, complete with all necessary third party content specified.
Determination of each student's strengths, weaknesses, knowledge, and skills prior to instruction.

Companies that maintain digital files of publisher titles and distribute them both to consumers and to other publisher-designated channels. These companies are cost-efffective alternatives for publishers that would like to avoid a substantial investment in Digital Asset management systems and digitization programs.
Books and content published in electronic formats for use either online or offline.
Projects undertaken with the purpose of helping publishers determine how to move from print to digital formats and channels.
Sales made directly to consumers.
The movement of content in finished form from publisher warehouses or servers to the ultimate consumer.
Business entities that form exclusive arrangements with either specific publishers or particular channels of distribution in order to increase the effectiveness of publishers in reaching that market.
The DOI is an identifier applied to items (physical or otherwise) to increase their findability on the web.
(D)igital (R)ights (M)anagement refers to systems of specifying and enforcing user rights over digital items such as eBooks or Music.

Books sold in digital format for consumption either online or offline. These editions may either consist of substantially the same content as the print edition or contain multimedia or interactive elements that extend substantially beyond the print edition.
Dedicated reading devices. These devices are specifically designed for reading books and perform only limited other functions.
Book retailers that are primarily focused on selling eBooks to consumers.
Software for reading books. This software runs on general purpose machines such as PCs, PDAs or smartphones.

Those stages of the publishing process between identification of the need for a particular publication through completion of the content prior to production.The editorial process consists of reviewing, making changes, and otherwise shaping a manuscript or compiled text to bring it to acceptable industry and commercial standards. Editing is a broad term that can represent corrections as minor as typos and grammar changes or as broad as suggestions for revision of a theme or premise.
Material delivered to support educational objectives.
The affixed paper, sometimes printed, sometimes blank, between the cover and the pages of a book, serving as a finishing effect and transition between the two.
English as a Second Language. Also known as ELT, or English Language Training.
Determining the manufactured price of a book given specifications, lead times and quantities.
Providing testimony in support of legal proceedings based on expert knowledge.
Folded and Gathered signatures that are used for reviewing purposes prior to binding, and may be stored to avoid the immediate cost of binding, or for use in custom publications.
Management of real estate, leases and facilities.
An illustration, image, or other graphic element within a book. A figure may also refer to a group of elements that together form a single entity set off within a body of text.

Higher quality paper that does not contain groundwood which has been coated by a process that consists of additives and is distributed by the rollers on the web. While this grade offers a good print surface it is not as favorable as the bladecoated process.

Groundwood which has been coated by a process that consists of additives and is distributed by the rollers on the web. While this grade offers a good print surface it is not as favorable as the bladecoated process.
Those functions of publishing that ensure the existence of sufficient cash to allow publishing operations.
The numeral used to represent page number.
Out of line notes that runs along the foot of a page that offers additional information to the body text.
Assessment that is an integral part of instruction that informs and guides teachers as they make instructional decisions.
Four Year institutions that grant Bachelors degrees
Also known as "C1"
That part of the text of a book that precedes the first page of the first chapter. Front matter is generally foliod with roman numerals.
Educational materials for the first two years of a four year program.
A group of definitions of key words within a book, usually found in the backmatter.
A government entity: local, state, or national.
A process used in printing to represent photographs or illustrations in process colors for print.
Institutions for post-secondary education
That sector of publishing focused primarily on providing content to institutions of higher learning for use in classrooms.
One of several types of graphic elements used to demonstrate a point visually within a book. The term may also be used loosely to describe all of the graphic elements within a volume.
A list of all of the titles of the graphic elements within a book, usually found within the frontmatter and typically citing the page number where each can be found.

A type of graphic element found in a book that makes or describes a point visually. Images are typically created by means of a photographic process, and include reference to xrays, CT scans, and other radiographic views.
Post sales support to assist instructors in using educational materials.
Booksellers not affiliated with a major chain.
An alphabetized list of important terms and concepts in a book accompanied by the page reference of each.

Identification and structuring of the key concepts in a book, linking them to the specific pages on which they are found. Traditionally indexing is accomplished after the typeset pages have stabilized where there is little chance of reflow - generally after the first pass through composition. With XML it is possible to link concepts directly to their appearance in the manuscript via internal references that allow dynamic index creation without concern for reflow.
Trade magazines focused on the book publishing industry
Also known as "C3"
Also known as "C2"
That part of the sales function comprised by internal selling staff as opposed to the field-based staff. Inside sales most commonly refers to telephone sales.
A non-education, non-government institution such as a hospital.
Pedagogical design of courseware consisting of multimedia and interactive elements.
Didactic material delivered in a variety of formats for the purpose of competence in a domain.
In most US publishing sectors International refers to non-U.S. sales channels.
When the introduction is a commentary on the book, and not strictly part of the content of the book, it will often be placed in the frontmatter instead of the body matter.
Management of finished goods inventory. This generally includes forecasting the need for stock over time, and determining the quantity and timing delivery.
A paper cover made to fit loosely around a book to protect or enhance it aesthetically.
Textual components that are found on the cover, jacket, or spine of a book. Copy normally includes bibliographic information, information about the author and information about the book or series.
That sector of publishing focused on providing content to pre-elementary, elementary, and secondary schools for use in the classroom.
A self-contained collection of assets placed in a pedagogical context that is used to teach or learn a particular objective within a course of study.
Management of agreements among authors, customers, and other partners.
Legal publishing
An institution that loans books to its patrons for either on-site or offsite use.

A (L)earning (M)anagement (S)ystem is a system used to manage classroom and online delivery of education. It generally consists of a roster, calendar and assignment list. It can also be referred to as an LCMS (Learning Content Management System) or CMS (Course Management System), not to be confused with a Content Management System.
All of those steps necessary to create printed books. These generally include paper buying, text printing, cover printing, component printing and binding.
The area of the page on all four sides of the text box. Margins include head margin, foot margin, gutter margin and outer margin.
Out of line notes that are placed in the margin of a page that offers additional information to the body text.
Development of business plans in support of entry into a new market.
Creation of demand for content.
Extranets and web sites devoted to furthering the publishing industry.
Retailers that sell a wide variety of merchandise to consumers often at a significant discount.
An XML markup language used for mathematical equations.
Trade magazines, websites and other similar resources that report on activities within the industry.
Media presented in a primarily textual manner for the main purpose of reading.
Data about content. This usually refers to descriptive, bibliographic data about titles, but can also include formatting, structural and administrative information.
A direct marketing technique in which books or other goods are sent on a periodic basis unless the customer sends a refusal notice prior to the shipment occurring.
Utilization of offshore vendors for any of the major publishing functions, composition, printing, etc.
Retailers that sell primarily physical books to consumers online.
Those functions n
Diagnostic assessment of publishing (or other) operations to examine effectiveness and efficiency at accomplishing organizational objectives.
The management of customer orders from entry, availability check, and pricing through dispatch for fulfillment.
Projects involving definition of organization structures and staff "right sizing" to better achieve the objectives of the organization.
An inventory status indicating that no further printings are planned, but avoiding an Out of Print (OP) classification that would lead to rights reversion.
An stock classification indicating that the title is not available and will not be reprinted. Declaring a title out of print is a first step in reverting rights.

A publishing strategy in which a third party assembles all of the content necessary for publication into final form prior to delivery to the publisher. Packaging can also include any necessary manufacturing steps.
The content contained on a single side of a single leaf of a book.
Purchasing of paper for printing operations.
The highest level of grouping of content within a book. A Part will generally contain multiple chapters.
A minor grant of rights on a non-exclusive basis generally to allow the use of an excerpt in another publication.

Digital printing used in book publishing for short print runs (as low as runs of a single unit). POD printing is used for pre-publication of galleys, for life-of-print printing where traditional prining would be excessively expensive, or end-of-life titles where demand is low and the cost of carrying inventory isn't justified.
Books and content published in ink on paper formats
Acquiring printed books from printers.
Printing and binding of complete books.
The stages of the publishing process from essential completion of the editorial content through initial publication.
Projects undertaken to increase the amount of output that can be generated by a given number of people.
Institutions providing trade and para-professional education.These can also be called "Career" or "For Profit" post-secondary institutions.
Trafficking and management of production schedules
Determining the overall schedule of a project relative to date of publication.
The reading and markup of typeset pages to identify errors that have been introduced during various production steps. These will be corrected in the various correction passes.
A library associated with a town or city.
The major activities of a publishing concern.
The activities associated with creating products for sale and distribution.
Pointers to other content. In books these are often by figure, chapter or page number. In electronic materials references are executed with links.
Content provided for occasional use to answer specific questions.
That sector of publishing focused primarily on providing content for religious use, whether for study or devotional use.
Business entities that sell primarily to consumers.
That function of publishing responsible for managing rights acquired from and licensed to third parties.
The text across the bottom margin of a page that is used for page navigation. The running foot can include title, author, chapter, folio or other information depending on the book design.
The text across the top margin of a page that is used for page navigation. The running head can include title, author, chapter, folio or other information depending on the book design.
Customer contact through placement of order.
From a publisher's perspective, the route through which content moves to the ultimate consumer. The channel is generally named for the location in which the first sale is made.
An institution for pre-Kindergarten, Kindergarten, primary or secondary education.
A library associated with a primary or secondary school.
A grouping of content below the chapter level.
Out of line notes that runs along the side of a page encroaching into the text box that offer additional information to the body text.

concept.examples: Immersive environments providing a model of real-world behavior. Classic examples include The Beer Game for supply chain simulation and Mike's Bikes for accounting. Case studies are a form of simulation.

concept.definition: Comparing the first and last word on each page to ensure that no content has been dropped during composition.
Proofreading using an electronic copy of the pages. Soft proofing can save considerable time and cost by avoiding the printing and shipping of proofs.
Business entities that sell items other than books primarily to consumers.
Standards used in the publishing industry and organizations responsible for their development and maintenance.
(S)cientific, (T)echnical, and (M)edical publishing actually consists of Science, Computing, Architecture, Engineering, Construction, Medicine and Healthcare publishing.

That function of publishing that determines positioning of the publishing concern relative to the market, customers and competitors and ensures correct allocation of resources to achieve the business objectives.
Student Information Systems are used by educational institutions to capture information on enrolled student including their personal information, academic records, and demographics

Summative assessment is a test given at the end of a term, chapter, semester, etc. to evaluate the knowledge of the student. High-stakes tests such as ACT, GRE, SAT, and the WASL are also summative assessments.
Organizations that aren't part of the industry value chain, but that provide support of various types to members of the value chain.
Systems design and integration services.
Tools and systems used to manipulate information used in publishing content.
Management of information systems and business technology to support the publishing enterprise.
Management of data centers.
The area of the page used to contain the main content.
Tools for organizing, sequencing and offering content.
That sector of publishing focused primarily on consumers.
Movement of books from printer to warehouse (inbound transportation) or from warehouse to customer (outbound transportation).
Interactive educational content in which the student steps through a solution to learn problem solving. Tutorials can be either instructor mediated, or self-study.
Two Year institutions that grant Associates degrees
Materials used in years 3-4 of a 4 year college program.
Management of vendors including identification, qualification, sourcing, negotiation, and vendor performance tracking.
Post secondary institutions with a mission of teaching a trade.

The function of a company that is responsible for holding finished goods awaiting shipment to customers. A warehouse generally is associated with the receipt, put-away, storage, selection, shipping of books. It also generally handles customer returns.
Business entities that buy books from publishers and distributors and sell to retailers
e(X)tensible (M)arkup (L)anguage is used to decrease cost of production and increase the ability to re-use content for multiple formats or multiple editions.
